Award.AwardTitle: Completing, Validating, and Linking Learning Trajectories for K-8 Rational Number Reasoning Tied to the Common Core Standards

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will build and validate learning trajectories (LTs) in mathematics for fraction, ratio, and for decimal and percent to represent learning by grades 3-7 students. A system will be developed to automate data collection for field testing assessment items to determine students' attainment of proficiency levels. Three LTs will be produced and validated along with over 125 assessment items for each of these three trajectories. These assessment items will be useful for diagnosing student learning. Technologies such as mobile phones, tablets, and computers will be used to deliver, analyze, and report diagnostic data on students. The learning trajectories will be available both electronically and in print. The levels of proficiencies will be provided with the outcome spaces, the exemplary items, the student work, and videos of student responses. Publications will provide data on analysis of the diagnostic items and assessments. The project will be done by researchers at the North Carolina State University in collaboration with RoleModel Software Inc.,and the University of Maryland.

The learning trajectories will be developed through literature reviews, whole class teaching experiments, clinical interviews, and large-scale assessments. Students in grade 3 will be observed and interviewed while engaging in work on fractions, ratios, decimal, and precents. Some of these students will be observed longitudinally over the two years. Other students from grades 4 through 8 will be interviewed. For each of the three trajectories, about 150 assessment items will be developed and field tested with a large group.

Three learning trajectories will be developed and made available electronically with supporting materials. The learning trajectories will be done in coordination with the Common Core State Standards (CCSS) in mathematics. Because the learning trajectories and materials will be informative to teachers who will be implementing the CCSS, the work has the potential to appeal to and reach a very large audience. Publications will provide data on analysis of the diagnostic items and assessments. The researchers will seek ways for a greater audience to have access to the software for accessing and retrieving items.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award led to the production of two websites used by teachers across the country to learn about the research on learning trajectories in mathematics and use it to improve instruction.

Turnonccmath (turnonccmath.net) is an open resource that synthesizes research connected to 18 mathematics learning trajectories spanning grades K-8. It contains problems and student solutions to make explicit the kinds of thinking children use as they progress through mathematical content, with references to the relevant research literature. This website presents learning trajectories as progressions of common core standards at one or more grade levels (figure 1). The turnonccmath.net site is used extensively, both nationally and internationally. The user base is tens of thousands. Presentations were given in nine states (NC, KY, CO, WA, MI, WV, ME, NJ, TX).

 

Figure 1: The turnonccmath site with a learning trajectory for fractions shown.

  Math-Mapper 6-8 (sudds.co) is a Digital Learning System that introduces a next generation means to scaffold coherence in a world of open resources. It does so using a learning map, aligned to but not dependent on Common Core State Standards. This Digital Learning System was funded collaboratively with the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Through the map, teachers can see the nine big ideas of middle grades math (figure 2) and explore their foundation in learning trajectories, which describe the common landmarks and challenges students encounter in learning the nine big ideas. A set of diagnostic assessments aligned to the proficiency levels of the learning trajectories give students and teachers immediate information on what the students have learned and what they still need to know.

Figure 2: Nine big ideas of middle school math

  The Intellectual Merit of the work rests in how it leverages current research to help students and teachers know more about student progress in highly valid and actionable ways. The sequencer and resourcer tools pioneer a flexible means to align with any curricula and supplement it with curated resources linked to the map. Finally, the research from the project demonstrates how design-based implementation research can be conducted in partnership with multiple sites serving diverse student populations and lead to iterative improvement in instruction and an ongoing validation process for the assessments.

  The diagnostic assessments developed in this project pioneer a new form of assessment, allowing teachers to give tests and receive real-time data on student progress along learning trajectories. The assessments provide valuable information about where students are in their thinking and how this relates to instructional goals. A key component of the project was communicating a class’s progress through a learning trajectory to teachers in a way that showed the variation in student thinking. Interactive heatmaps were designed and implemented to describe how a class responded to items in a particular learning trajectory. The structure of a heatmap is described in figure 3. Within the heatmap, teachers can interactively link to the items on the test to promote rich discussion of items or link to more information on individual students. Teachers found the heatmap intuitive and informative, helping them reach individual students, group students for precise help, or to reteach the class.

Figure 3: Heatmap showing class progress along a Learning Trajectory.

The work has resulted in empowering students as partners in their assessment. They receive real-time data showing how they performed on an assessment (figures 4 and 5), with breakdown scores describing topic-by-topic results. The system provides students opportunities to revise and resubmit their work on specific items, and they report feeling increased ownership of their learning.

Figure 4: Student report with breakdown score and item feedback.

The Broad Impact of the project rests in its open access to a variety of communities along with the widespread dissemination it is receiving. Guests may access the site for the learning map, the underlying learning trajectories, and the curricular resources. Schools or districts with accounts gain access to the assessment and reporting tools, as well as a sequencer that teachers can use to plan out an instructional year. The curriculum materials used in SUDDS research are also made freely available through the site.

  Confrey’s work has been well received by many audiences. Confrey served on the Future of NAEP Panel, and the Common Core Validation Committee, and hosted a national meeting with support from the Pearson Foundation on diagnostic assessment. She and her team have published and presented their work to various audiences, including NCTM, NCSM, and NSF. Confrey received and approved multiple requests from scholars to use the learning trajectories in their studies (national and international). She licensed the material from NCSU and has a start up, The Math Door. Discussions are underway with a variety of possible partners (publishers, measurement companies, and technology firms) to bring the use of Math-Mapper 6-8 to scale.

Figure 5: Students discussing a score report.
